msItem.incipit: SANCTI VIRI QUO APUD DEUM ALTIUS
msItem.note: Explicit in the unbound folios of the volume.

supportDesc.support: Thin, fine quality parchment. After its restoration the shelfmark identifies two seperated items: (a) the non-palimpsest folios (ff. 1-201) that remain bound in codex form; (b) the palimpsest bifolios of the volume that survive unbound in paper folders grouped by signature. The current entry describes the bound codex.

extent.measure: The bound part of the codex recentior has 201 ff. The entire manuscript, both bound and unbound parts, had 340 ff.

supportDesc.foliation: Duplicate foliation in red ink and pencil.

collation.signatures: Signutures in Latin numerals at the last verso of each quire.

supportDesc.condition: Humidity damage, faded ink, tears and missing corners of the folios of the first quire.

scriptDesc.p: Eighth-century 'Luxeuil' minuscule; expert flowing cursive minuscule; letters lean slightly to the left (C.L.A. 497).

decoDesc.decoNote: Large Merovingian initials in green, red and yellow with fish and bird motifs (C.L.A. 497).
Rubrics in interchanging red and green ornamented uncial characters.
Two- or three-line incipit for each book. The first line in red and green ornamented uncial script, while the rest in semi-uncial red characters.

additions.p: Marginal note by a Veronese hand on f. 9v. Additions and corrections possibly by Pacificus of Verona on ff. 137v, 160, 187v, etc. (C.L.A. 497).

binding.p: The codex was rebound in the 20th century between two wooden plates with a dark brown leather joint. It features occidental binding with three raised nerve bands.
binding.decoNote: Shelfmark in latin numerals stamped in gold and centered towards the bottom of the spine.
binding.condition: The original binding does not survive. The codex was rebound in the 20th century.

supportDesc.support: Partially palimpsest. Parchment either of thin, fine quality or reused from three codices antiquiores. After its restoration the shelfmark identifies two seperated items: (a) the non-palimpsest folios (ff. 1-201) that remain bound in codex form; (b) the palimpsest bifolios of the volume that survive unbound in paper folders grouped by signature. The current entry describes the unbound part of the codex.

extent.measure: The bound part of the codex recentior has 201 ff. The entire manuscript, both bound and unbound parts, had 340 ff.

supportDesc.foliation: Duplicate foliation in red ink and pencil. Numbers 327-330 skipped.

collation.signatures: Signutures in Latin numerals at the last verso of each quire.

supportDesc.condition: Humidity damage, faded ink, tears and missing corners of the folios of the first quire.

scriptDesc.p: Eighth-century 'Luxeuil' minuscule; expert flowing cursive minuscule; letters lean slightly to the left (C.L.A. 497).

decoDesc.decoNote: Large Merovingian initials in green, red and yellow with fish and bird motifs (C.L.A. 497).
Rubrics in interchanging red and green ornamented uncial characters.
Two- or three-line incipit for each book. The first line in red and green ornamented uncial script, while the rest in semi-uncial red characters.

binding.p: Unbound. After a restoration event the shelfmark identifies two now seperated items: (a) the non-palimpsest folios (ff. 1-201) that remain bound in codex form; (b) the (partially) palimpsest bifolios of the volume that survive unbound in paper folders grouped by signature.

supportDesc.support: Parchment later reused for the Moralia of Gregorius Magnus.
supportDesc.collation:
Baschera (1999, pp. 40-42) describes the Virgilian codex as probably originally having 52 gatherings.
No signatures discernible.
supportDesc.condition: Extensive damage in the majority of bifolios from the use of various types of chemical reagents.

layout.p: 13 long lines with wide margins for scholia. Ruling on the hair side (C.L.A. 498).

handDesc.p: Single, fifth-century hand for the main textblock. Same-period scholia by two hands in mixed uncial and eraly half-uncial (C.L.A. 498).

scriptDesc.p: Fifth-century rustic capitals in the main textblock.

additions.p: In the intentionally wide margins fifth-century commentary by two hands in mixed uncial and early half-uncial (C.L.A. 498).

supportDesc.support: Parchment later reused for the Moralia of Gregorius Magnus.
supportDesc.collation:
The 60 surviving folios come from 15 different gatherings, but the original codex was composed of 56.
Signature survive in 4 folios in the format "q." followed by the respective roman numeral.
supportDesc.condition: Damage in the majority of bifolios from the use of various types of chemical reagents. Some applications successful.

handDesc.p: Regular uncial of the oldest type. Scholia in tiny Greek uncial in a current expert hand (C.L.A. 499).

scriptDesc.p: Regular uncial of the oldest type (C.L.A. 499).

decoDesc.decoNote: Large initial at the beginning of each column in similar ink to the text.
Initial and final rubrics in large uncial accupying an entire column.

additions.p: Greek scholia in a tuny uncial of the oldest type.

history.provenance: Rewritten probably at Luxeuil at the beginning of the 8th century.

msItem.title: Introduction to Plato's work and summary to the platonic corpus.
Introduction; summaries to Charmides (Χαρμίδης), Theages (Θεάγης), Ion (Ἴων), On Justice (Περὶ Δικαίου), On Virtue (Περὶ Ἀρετῆς), Minos (Μίνως), and Erastai (Ἐρασταί) (Gysembergh & Zingg, 2023).
Introduction; summaries to Cratylus (Κρατύλος) and the beginning of Philebus (Φίληβος) (Gysembergh & Zingg, 2023).
Summary of books one, two, five, nine, ten of the Republic (Πολιτεία) (Gysembergh & Zingg, 2023).

supportDesc.support: Parchment later reused for the Moralia of Gregorius Magnus.
supportDesc.condition: Extensive damage in the majority of bifolios from the use of various types of chemical reagents.

history.provenance: Rewritten probably at Luxeuil at the beginning of the 8th century.

supportDesc.support: Parchment later reused for the Moralia of Gregorius Magnus.
supportDesc.condition: Damage in the majority of bifolios from the use of various types of chemical reagents.

history.provenance: Rewritten probably at Luxeuil at the beginning of the 8th century.

custEvent.p: Restoration event where the palimpsest quires were seperated from the main volume at the Vatican Library. Interventions according to the method of Franz Ehrle, Prefect of the BAV, to stabilise the parchment using gelatine (Gysembergh & Zingg, 2023).
A label on the back cover reads: "LABORATORIO DI RESTAURO DEL LIBRO presso la Biblioteca Capitolare Verona 1970".
